page.title: 19FINZEAN STORES:1958-1985.
page.content: {Finzean Shop}in 1958 was a General Merchant's business, selling almost everything. There was also a van going round the valley , selling groceries and general merchandise. There was one petrol pump, worked by hand, the selling price of petrol being four shillings and sixpence (24p)per gallon {The price}of goods remained relatively stable,changing about once every six months until decimalisation came when prices increased monthly. {The van}had to be withdrawn because of increasing overhead expenses. The big problem now for country shops is the popularity of the supermarket and the greater mobility of the shopper. They must keep open after normal hours and cater for passing tourist trade with soft drinks, ice-cream, confectionary and local produce to survive.
